(b) Formal submissions were provided by a number of tax experts and stakeholders. In line with standard consultation protocols, it is expected the submissions received will be made publicly available, unless those who provided the submission requested they remain confidential.

subdebateinfo.title: Future of Financial Advice Reform Package (Question No. 37)

p.span: Future of Financial Advice Reform Package
(Question No. 37)
Mr Bowen asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 12 December 2013:
(1) Does a discussion paper exist, or has there been a consultation process, on proposed changes to the Future of Financial Advice Reform Package (FOFA).
(2) What election commitments did the Government make on implementing changes to the FOFA.
(3) Will the Government consider ruling out changes to the reformed remuneration practices and the requirement that advice is provided in the best interests of the consumer, if not, why not.
Mr Hockey: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(1) The Government has undertaken consultations with industry and consumer stakeholders on the proposed changes to FOFA. Further consultations will occur as part of finalising the associated legislative amendments.
(2) The election commitments made by the Government were identified in The Coalition's Policy to Boost Productivity and Reduce Regulation.
(3) Details of the FOFA amendments are listed in the Assistant Treasurer's media statement dated 20 December 2013.
Treasury: Staffing
(Question No. 38)
Mr Bowen asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 12 December 2013:
As at 12 December 2013, how many Treasury officials, including those on leave, worked in the Office of the Treasurer, by classification.
Mr Hockey: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

As at 12 December 2013 there were two currently serving Treasury officials (ie employees not employed under the MOPS Act) working in the Office of the Treasurer. One employee was classified as an EL1 (Acting), and the other was an EL2.

subdebateinfo.title: North West Queensland Drought: Financial Support (Question No. 39)

p.span: North West Queensland Drought: Financial Support
(Question No. 39)
Mr Katter asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on 11 February 2014 :

What financial support can be made available to students whose families are affected by the drought in North West Queensland, to continue to attend to their education at boarding schools where this is the only available learning option, and is costing isolated families in the vicinity of $27,000 to $30,000 per child per year
Mr Pyne: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

The Department of Education provides no direct financial support to students whose families are affected by drought in North West Queensland. The Department however works closely with the Department of Social Services, who manage the Assistance for Isolated Children Scheme, to ensure that the educational needs of rural and regional students are being supported.
Productivity Commission
(Question No. 40)
Dr Leigh asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 11 February 2014:

What number of enquiries has this Government initiated through the Productivity Commission, and of those inquiries, has he instructed the Productivity Commission to consider any requirements beyond its regular criteria; if so, what are these requirements, and why were they considered.
Mr Hockey: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
Since September the Government has provided the Productivity Commission with four new references:
an inquiry into Australia's automotive manufacturing industry (reference received 30 October 2013, final report due 31 March 2014);
an inquiry into public infrastructure (reference received 13 November 2013, final report due May 2014);
an inquiry into childcare and early childhood learning (reference received 22 November, final report due 31 October 2014); and
an inquiry into Tasmanian shipping and freight (reference received 29 November 2013, final report due 7 March 2014).

The references provide for a comprehensive examination of relevant issues in each inquiry area, and are made pursuant to Parts 2 and 3 of the Productivity Commission Act 1998. The Terms of Reference for these inquiries were developed through the usual procedures and are available at:
www.pc.gov.au/projects
Health: Wind Farms
(Question No. 46)
Mr Thomson asked the Minister for Health, in writing, on 11 February 2014:

span.span: In respect of the National Health and Medical Research Council report into wind farm
(a) why has it not yet been publicly released;
(b) when will it be publicly released; and
(c) why is the Government commissioning a new study before the release of the report.

p.span:
Mr Dutton
: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
a) and b)
The draft 'Information Paper: Evidence on Wind Farms and Human Health' was released on 24 February 2014.
c) In response to community concern over wind farms and human health, the Australian Government committed to establish an independent research program on this issue.

The National Health and Medical Research Council's (NHMRC) independent review of the published literature has identified that the existing body of evidence on the potential human health effects of wind farms is small and of poor quality. Further research of the highest standard is warranted.

NHMRC intends to announce a targeted call for research once the additional literature submitted during public consultation on the draft 'Information Paper: Evidence on Wind Farms and Human Health' has been considered.
